structuralFindings.rationale: Apple is reorganizing AI work along functional lines — splitting what was John Giannandrea's centralized AI team across multiple divisions (robotics under hardware, Siri under Vision Pro team, Foundation Models under Craig Federighi, other AI work under Sabih Khan and Eddy Cue). This is a classic hub-and-spoke model: central standards and research (now under Amar Subramanya for ML research, AI safety, and evaluation) with distributed execution in product groups. The Zurich Vision Lab and Shenzhen research facility suggest a geographically distributed research operation. Apple's functional organizational structure (organized around expertise rather than products) reinforces this hybrid model.
structuralFindings.aiTeamStructure: Apple restructured its AI organization in late 2025. John Giannandrea (SVP Machine Learning & AI Strategy) stepped down, moving to an advisory role before retirement in Spring 2026. Amar Subramanya (former Microsoft AI VP and Google Gemini engineering head) became VP of AI, reporting to Craig Federighi. Subramanya's remit includes ML research, AI safety, and evaluation across device, edge, and cloud environments. Robotics moved under hardware chief (likely John Ternus), Siri under Vision Pro team (Mike Rockwell leading Siri redesign), and Foundation Models under Craig Federighi. Operations and Services elements moved under Sabih Khan and Eddy Cue respectively. Research labs in Zurich (Vision Lab), Shenzhen (China hub), and main operations in California and Seattle.

structuralFindings.investmentSignals: Massive investment: $500B+ in US operations including AI-focused R&D and server infrastructure in 2025. New AI server farm in Houston using custom Apple silicon. Custom AI chips in development including 'Baltra' server processor. 12,000 hires in past year, 40% in R&D with 'many focused on AI.' Cook stated Apple will 'spend what it takes to compete.' FY2026 record R&D spending. Tim Cook is open to AI acquisitions — a notable shift for Apple which historically preferred building. Partnership with Google on next-gen Apple Foundation models and OpenAI for ChatGPT integration in Siri.

observableMarkers.reportingStructure: AI VP (Subramanya) reports to Craig Federighi (Software SVP), not directly to CEO. This is a shift from Giannandrea's SVP-level reporting. AI work distributed across multiple SVPs (Federighi, Khan, Cue, hardware chief, Vision Pro).
observableMarkers.resourceAllocation: Dedicated and growing: $500B US operations investment, AI server farm, custom AI chips. R&D spend at record levels. Hiring heavily weighted toward AI (40% of new hires). Ring-fenced major projects: Siri overhaul, Apple Foundation Models, Apple Intelligence.
observableMarkers.timeHorizons: Mixed: Siri overhaul targeting Spring 2026 (12-18 month horizon). Apple Intelligence rolling out 2025-2026. Long-term research through Zurich Vision Lab and ML research publications. Cook frames AI as 'once-in-a-generation shift' — long-term strategic priority.
observableMarkers.decisionRights: Historically centralized under Giannandrea; now distributed across functional leaders (Federighi, Khan, Cue, hardware). Amar Subramanya provides central coordination for ML research and AI safety/evaluation. Product decisions likely with product leaders.
observableMarkers.metrics: Consumer adoption of Apple Intelligence features. iPhone upgrade cycles (FY2026 driven by iPhone 17 'AI supercycle'). Services revenue growth (14-15% YoY). Device differentiation through on-device AI. Privacy and quality benchmarks — Cook and Federighi emphasize 'Apple quality' standards.

summary: Apple is restructuring its AI organization from a centralized model under John Giannandrea to a hybrid/hub-and-spoke model with AI work distributed across functional leaders (Federighi for Foundation Models/Siri, hardware for robotics, services under Cue, operations under Khan). The new VP of AI (Amar Subramanya, ex-Microsoft/Google) reports to Craig Federighi and provides central coordination for ML research, AI safety, and evaluation. This reflects Apple's traditional functional organizational structure applied to AI. Investment is massive ($500B+ US operations, custom AI chips, 12K hires with 40% in R&D focused on AI), and Cook has positioned AI as a 'once-in-a-generation shift' requiring Apple to 'spend what it takes to compete.'

conferenceFindings: Apple sponsors major ML conferences (NeurIPS 2025, EMNLP 2025) and publishes research openly through machinelearning.apple.com. No evidence of Apple executives giving keynotes at AI/ML conferences — consistent with Apple's historically secretive approach. Key executives (Cook, Federighi) discuss AI in product launch keynotes (WWDC) and earnings calls rather than research conferences.
